stream_context.summary: Kaze continues a large refactor of the SM64/RTY codebase (nearing completion), reports beta-testing progress, and implements/finishes an Overworld mission where giant crabs block koi fish; freeing the fish sets up a new secret-side-level unlock that uses the koi circling a “hugging Yoshis” statue as a player hint. He also identifies cutscene/NPC-dialog issues in water, proposes a time-stop-based cutscene approach, and starts designing a progress-dependent dialogue-tree system for Yoshi NPCs. Hardware/emulator compatibility philosophy and planned Analog 3D testing/drama video come up repeatedly.
stream_context.significance_reason: A feature-sized Overworld sequence (crabs blocking koi → freeing fish → koi hinting/unlocking a side level) is implemented to a ‘considered done’ state, with follow-on design decisions locked in (unlock condition, hinting approach, visual statue anchor). In parallel, Kaze outlines a major upcoming system (dynamic NPC dialogue trees) and confirms the project is nearing the end of a long refactor/beta-test phase.

findings.summary: Kaze says he has spent weeks refactoring large portions of the codebase and is in the final stretch (roughly 80–90% done), describing the refactor as making systems simpler and more straightforward; audio refactoring is deferred with the hope that Sauraen/Saren can help.

Beta testing is reportedly complete for the first 10 courses except for two courses still being reworked by Biobak; Kaze is currently re-testing Course 11 and anticipates Course 12 will need significant testing/fixes.

Overworld progression is clarified: at ~55 stars, three giant crabs spawn in the river, bully/block the koi, and the player must ground pound them into retreat; once freed, the koi become friendly and serve as guidance for unlocking a large side level behind a gate.

A crash affecting the koi fish behavior was traced to a C switch/case scoping issue leading to null pointers—an example Kaze cites as why newer C standards discourage defining variables inside switch cases.
findings.quote: This is why modern versions of C do not let you define variables inside switch cases. Because you get null pointers like that, and you wouldn’t even notice.

findings.summary: Kaze finds a design/implementation constraint: his NPC dialogue routine (setNPCDialog) forces Mario into an NPC-reading action that cannot occur while swimming, breaking the fish-statue unlock sequence if triggered in water; he decides a time-stop approach is likely the cleanest solution for water-adjacent cutscenes.

He notes a specific bug to track: the “water star collection” cutscene does not end (Mario remains unable to move), and he suspects it relates to how cutscenes are handled and/or flags like ‘do not warp out’ not being correctly OR’ed in for that star.

The koi-based hint/unlock design evolves during the stream: initially ‘three circles around the temple’ to unlock, then reduced (two circles discussed), and finally anchored to circling a specific mid-river landmark to make the intention more readable; chat suggests adding a more explicit visual cue like a whirlpool and/or world shake as feedback.

Kaze articulates his puzzle/hinting philosophy: he starts with the most opaque/offensive version of a concept, then iteratively adds hints if players struggle; he also likes letting skilled players unlock secrets accidentally early so they feel unusually clever.
findings.quote: I always start off with the most offensive version of a concept. And then we slowly turn the offensiveness down.

findings.summary: A new Overworld landmark is created as the koi-circling target: a large statue of two Yoshis hugging (dubbed “the lovers”), intended to be visually distinctive enough to communicate ‘circle me’ without explicit UI.

Platform support stance is explicit: Kaze targets Real N64 hardware and Project64 with GlideN64 first; other emulators are treated as best-effort, and if an emulator fails while hardware works, he considers it the emulator’s problem. He also notes Ares-specific input unbinding and occasional flicker not seen on console, and complains that Parallel Launcher updates have historically broken compatibility near releases.
findings.quote: When I make the hack, there’s two things I care about: the real Nintendo 64, and Project64 with GlideN64. If another emulator doesn’t run on it… then I say fix the emulator.

findings.summary: Kaze explains that RNG in the project is currently non-deterministic (potentially influenced by external factors), and he considers adding a speedrunner-facing boot-time button combo that forces determinism by sweeping/initializing memory at game start.

He says he is seeking a sponsor for an upcoming video (about exclamation boxes) and describes sponsor-less uploads as financially negative once editing costs are considered; a separate ‘guns/trucks’ Mario video is hard to sponsor due to brand-safety concerns.
findings.quote: Not having a sponsor is expensive. It means I pay more for the editing than I get out of making the video—so it would be a better decision for me to not even upload a video at that point.

findings.summary: Kaze anticipates the Analogue 3D could become a major ‘YouTube drama’ moment for him; he plans to test it with dedicated N64 accuracy/performance test ROMs (from “HailToTheDumbo”) and explicitly separates respect for engineers from contempt for marketing claims he believes are misleading.
findings.quote: The people that worked on it, they’re really cool. What they did is cool as hell. The people that market the product, fuck them. They’re just lying to you.

findings.summary: Kaze mentions worsening wrist pain and considers taking time away from the PC, hinting at ongoing physical strain from sustained development/refactor work.

Next major content/system goals are laid out: finishing Overworld Yoshi houses, implementing progress-aware Yoshi NPC dialogue (a lightweight dialogue-tree system keyed to stars/flags/events), and potentially starting additional side levels (Manta Ray or Rainbow Slide).

biobak.summary: Kaze reports two of the first 10 courses are still being reworked by Biobak and will need additional testing, though preliminary tests are done.

findings.summary: Kaze references a large side level currently being built by Marty (a Japanese garden featuring a wizard). The new koi/circle mechanic in the Overworld is specifically designed to unlock access to this side area through a gate/entrance sequence.

Kaze discusses relying on (or at least being interested in) Sauraen/Saren’s help for deeper engine work—particularly audio refactoring for a potential royalty-free version—and separately engages with ideas about alternative OS/libultra approaches and hardware communication tradeoffs (threads vs direct hardware access).

key_stories.title: Finishing the giant-crabs vs koi Overworld mission and tying it to a side-level unlock
key_stories.summary: Kaze implements the remaining behavior for an Overworld encounter where giant crabs block koi fish, then designs the payoff: after freeing them, koi become friendly and guide the player to unlock a hidden side level. The sequence becomes a key example of how RTY layers ‘Overworld as level’ progression on top of SM64’s hub structure.
key_stories.challenge: Make crabs/fish behaviors reliable (spawns, actions, positioning) and turn the encounter into a readable, satisfying unlock path to a major side level (Marty’s).
key_stories.process: Debugs missing spawns (star-state gating), fixes fish placement/action logic, then prototypes koi circling behavior as a hint mechanic; iterates on how many laps/what landmark to circle and considers extra visual feedback (whirlpool/shake). Builds a placeholder ‘hugging Yoshis’ statue to serve as the focal point.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze calls the crab/fish piece effectively ‘done’ pending future bug-fixing during broader testing; the unlock path is now conceptually locked: 55-star crab event → free koi → koi circle statue → gate opens to side level.
key_stories.key_quote: So eventually… at 55 stars… three crabs appear in the river… you ground pound all the crabs… [then] the koi start swimming around the statue… and you have to follow the koi’s lead. And that opens the level.

key_stories.title: A crash rooted in C switch/case scoping becomes a ‘why refactoring matters’ moment
key_stories.summary: While testing koi behavior, Kaze hits repeatable crashes and traces them to a subtle C footgun: variables defined inside a switch case leading to null pointers. The debugging reinforces why he’s been refactoring aggressively and how fragile actor code can be in N64-era C patterns.
key_stories.challenge: Koi fish start crashing the game under specific action/animation conditions, blocking progress on the Overworld feature.
key_stories.process: Reproduces the crash, narrows it to the koi logic, inspects the control flow, and identifies the null pointer behavior caused by switch/case variable scoping; patches the logic and re-tests.
key_stories.outcome: Crash is resolved enough to proceed; Kaze resumes implementing the unlock sequence and marks the feature as largely complete with remaining edge-case bugs to be handled during formal testing.
key_stories.key_quote: This is why modern versions of C do not let you define variables inside switch cases.

key_stories.title: Cutscenes vs swimming: switching from NPC-dialog actions to time-stop cutscenes
key_stories.summary: As the koi/secret unlock begins to work, Kaze discovers the cutscene trigger relies on NPC-dialog action states that don’t exist for Mario while in water, breaking the experience in a water-adjacent area. He pivots toward time-stopping the game to stage the cutscene reliably, reframing how RTY handles ‘hub events.’
key_stories.challenge: The unlock hint/cutscene needs to trigger near/over water, but Mario can’t enter the NPC-reading action while swimming.
key_stories.process: Identifies setNPCDialog as the culprit and reasons through options (water-appropriate action state vs removing control). Concludes time-stop is simpler and more robust, then begins adjusting the cutscene behavior accordingly.
key_stories.outcome: A new direction is chosen: use time-stop as the backbone for these Overworld micro-cutscenes, with follow-up work needed to properly frame/zoom the camera on the gate/entrance.
key_stories.key_quote: Another thing is Mario doesn’t have an action state that allows him to watch stuff while he is in water… Actually we can just time stop the game. That’s probably easier.

key_stories.title: ‘Real N64 first’: defining emulator support boundaries while preparing Analogue 3D tests
key_stories.summary: Kaze lays out a clear support philosophy: optimize and validate on real N64 plus a single reference emulator path (PJ64 + GlideN64), and treat other emulation failures as emulator issues. In parallel, he prepares to test the Analogue 3D with specialized rendering/accuracy ROMs, expecting controversy over marketing claims.
key_stories.challenge: Keeping RTY stable across a fragmented emulator ecosystem while also evaluating new ‘hardware-like’ platforms making strong accuracy claims.
key_stories.process: States his target platforms, describes recurring problems (Ares input unbinding/flicker, Parallel updates breaking compatibility), and plans to use community-made test ROMs (HailToTheDumbo) to validate Analogue 3D rendering/performance and call out misleading marketing.
key_stories.outcome: A documentary-relevant stance is established: Kaze’s bar for ‘correct’ behavior is original hardware, not emulator consensus; Analogue 3D testing is positioned as potential public conflict/drama content.
key_stories.key_quote: If another emulator doesn’t run on it, then I say fix the emulator.

open_questions.topic: Overworld secret readability: koi circling + statue + whirlpool feedback
open_questions.context: The unlock for Marty’s side level depends on players interpreting koi behavior (circling) as an instruction to mimic, with debate over laps, landmark choice, and adding a whirlpool or shaking feedback.
questions: What did playtesting (or your own intuition) tell you about how quickly players understand ‘follow the koi and circle the statue’ without being told?
Why settle on 55 stars as the trigger for the crab event—was it pacing, difficulty gating, narrative, or just where the Overworld felt ready?
Did you end up adding a stronger mechanical feedback cue (whirlpool, statue rotation, world shake), and how did you decide what was ‘too obvious’ vs ‘too obscure’?

open_questions.topic: Cutscene system design: time-stop vs Mario action states
open_questions.context: NPC dialog/cutscene triggering fails in water because Mario lacks a compatible action state; Kaze leans toward time-stopping to stage hub events robustly.
questions: What does your ‘time-stop cutscene’ system look like in RTY—what gets frozen, what still runs, and how do you avoid side effects (e.g., physics, camera, audio)?
How do you decide when a hub event should be a cutscene vs a purely player-driven discovery?
What’s your plan for making these cutscenes resilient across hardware/emulators given timing differences and input quirks?

open_questions.topic: Dynamic Yoshi NPC dialogue trees keyed to progress
open_questions.context: Kaze wants Yoshis to display different text depending on stars collected, specific flags/events, etc., and brainstorms a node/leaf structure; he also declares current Yoshi talk code ‘incorrigible’ and implies a rewrite.
questions: What was so broken or limiting about the existing Yoshi talk implementation that made you decide to rewrite it instead of incrementally cleaning it?
How do you want dialogue to be authored—hardcoded structs, data tables, a custom script, or tooling inside your editor?
What’s the design goal for Yoshi dialogue variation: flavor, hinting, narrative continuity, or all three—and how do you keep it from becoming a combinatorial explosion?
How will you distinguish ‘Yoshi with purpose’ vs ‘no-purpose’ Yoshis in production so the Overworld stays readable and not cluttered with accidental hints?

open_questions.topic: Non-deterministic RNG and a speedrunner-facing determinism toggle
open_questions.context: Kaze says RNG is currently not deterministic and could be affected by externalities; he considers a boot-time button combo that sweeps memory to make runs deterministic for speedrunners.
questions: What exactly makes RNG non-deterministic in your current build—timing jitter, uninitialized memory, hardware entropy, or something else?
How would the ‘memory sweep’ determinism mode work technically, and what risks does it introduce (boot time, compatibility, unintended bias)?
Would you treat the determinism toggle as an official ‘speedrun rules’ feature, and how would you communicate/verify it for communities?

open_questions.topic: Audio refactor and the possibility of a royalty-free RTY build
open_questions.context: Kaze says he hasn’t refactored audio and mentions the sound engine would ideally be reworked if RTY ever needed a royalty-free version, hoping Saren/Sauraen can help.
questions: What parts of the current audio stack are most entangled with copyrighted/legacy assets—sequence data, instruments, mixing code, or something else?
What would a ‘royalty-free RTY’ actually change: music only, SFX, voice clips, or the whole audio pipeline?
What help do you specifically need from Saren/Sauraen—reverse engineering, toolchain work, new engine code, or asset conversion?
